title: Space & Balance
description: Uncover how you navigate closeness and independence.

questions.text: What's my pattern when I feel overwhelmed by closeness?
choices: I communicate my need for space

therapeutic.rationale: How we handle too much closeness reveals attachment style. Rarely-overwhelmed suggests secure or anxious attachment; alone-time needers have healthy self-awareness; pull-backers may not recognize their pattern; space-communicators have learned healthy expression. Avoidant attachers often create distance unconsciously when closeness feels threatening.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different overwhelm responses can confuse partners. The rarely-overwhelmed may not understand their partner's need to pull back. Name the pattern.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared overwhelm patterns help you understand each other—but two pullers-back may create excessive distance. Be intentional about reconnecting.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When does closeness feel like too much? What do you do? Does your partner know this is about needing space, not about them?

questions.text: How do I recover after we've had a conflict?
choices: I want to discuss what happened

therapeutic.rationale: Post-conflict recovery needs reveal attachment soothing patterns. Verbal-reassurance seekers need explicit repair; physical-reconnectors need touch to restore safety; alone-time needers must self-regulate first; discussion-wanters need processing. Matching your repair style to your partner's recovery needs speeds reconnection.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different recovery needs extend post-conflict distance. The verbal-reassurance seeker feels abandoned by the alone-time needer. Ask: 'What would help us reconnect?'
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared recovery needs make repair intuitive. You'll naturally offer what helps because it's what would help you.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: After conflict, what do you need to feel reconnected? Does your partner know? What happens when you don't get it?

questions.text: What helps me feel that our bond is strong?

therapeutic.rationale: Bond-strength signals vary by attachment needs. Regular affection soothes anxious attachment; team stress-handling builds secure partnership; commitment actions reassure those with abandonment fears; deep conversations create intimacy for emotionally-oriented people. Knowing what signals bond-strength for your partner helps you provide it.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different bond signals mean you may feel differently about the relationship's strength at the same moment. The affection-needer may doubt when physical touch decreases even if conversations are deep.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared bond signals mean you'll both feel secure from the same behaviors. You're aligned on what makes the relationship feel strong.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What makes you feel your relationship is strong? When does the bond feel weak? What would reinforce your sense of security?

questions.text: How do I balance needing you and being independent?
choices: I lean toward needing you more

therapeutic.rationale: The need-independence balance reflects attachment style. Lean-toward-needing suggests anxious attachment; lean-toward-independence suggests avoidant attachment; good-balance suggests secure attachment; stress-shifting shows adaptability. The goal is flexible balance—able to depend and be independent based on context.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different balance points create the classic anxious-avoidant trap. The needing-more person may feel rejected by the independence-leaner; the independence-leaner may feel suffocated. Both are valid positions.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared balance orientation makes relationship calibration easier. Two independence-leaners may have a distant but functional relationship; two needing-more types may be closely intertwined.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Do you lean toward needing your partner or toward independence? Has this changed over time? What would help you find better balance?

questions.text: What would help me feel more securely attached to you?

therapeutic.rationale: What would increase security reveals unmet attachment needs. Communication consistency soothes contact-anxiety; physical affection fills touch needs; quality time addresses presence needs; verbal reassurance fills words-of-affirmation needs. This question directly asks: 'What do you need more of to feel safer with me?'
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different security-building needs guide where to invest relationship energy. Your partner is telling you exactly what they need to feel more secure. Provide it.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared security-building needs mean you both want more of the same thing. Focus your shared effort here.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What would make you feel more secure in your relationship? Have you asked for this? What's preventing you from getting it?
